text:
(Bloomberg) -- India has tweaked the terms for sale of its shares in Hindustan Petroleum Corp. to the country’s biggest explorer to avoid a mandatory open offer to minority shareholders, according to people with knowledge of the plan.






HPCL “will continue to be controlled by the government” through Oil & Natural Gas Corp., the Department of Investment and Public Asset Management said in a clarification on its website. The amendment to the terms will avoid triggering an open offer, which would have dragged the completion of the transaction and increased ONGC’s payout, said the people, who asked not to be identified citing rules.






The government is aiming to complete the transaction this financial year as part of its plan to achieve the target of over $11 billion from asset sales in the year ending March. The sale of its 51.11 percent holding in HPCL can fetch Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s administration about 330 billion rupees at today’s price, about half of its annual share sale aim.






ONGC is expected to get the final approval from its board within three months, according to the people. The state-run explorer may borrow about 250 billion rupees for funding the transaction, they said.






The state oil explorer may have to pay the government a price equivalent to the six-month average trading price of HPCL shares, the people said. ONGC and HPCL spokesmen were not available for comment.
title: India Is Said to Tweak HPCL Share Sale Terms to Skip Open Offer
